Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation2: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, phone in hand, typing out my daily update to my stepdad. He always wanted to know how my day went, what I ate, if I’d finished my homework. He said it made him feel included, and I knew how much it meant to him, especially since I’d only moved in a few months ago. Just as I was about to hit send, I heard a knock at the door. It was Mrs. Lee from next door, holding a bag of trash. “Would you mind if I put this in your bin? Ours is overflowing,” she asked, glancing at the half-empty bin by the curb. I remembered the building rules: we’re supposed to keep our own trash separate, but Mrs. Lee had always been kind to me. My phone buzzed again—my stepdad, asking if everything was okay since I hadn’t replied yet. I felt torn, caught between being the attentive step-child my dad wanted and the considerate neighbor Mrs. Lee needed. My heart pounded as I stood there, unsure which expectation to meet first.
